prior_works.title: Problem Complexity and Method Efficiency in Optimization
prior_works.role: Origin of mirror descent and non-Euclidean first-order methods
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper lifts the mirror descent paradigm introduced by Nemirovsky–Yudin from Euclidean spaces to the Wasserstein space, using a Bregman regularizer defined on probability measures.

prior_works.title: Relatively Smooth Convex Optimization by First-Order Methods, and Applications
prior_works.authors: Haihao Lu, Robert M. Freund, Yurii Nesterov
prior_works.role: Introduced relative smoothness/relative strong convexity framework and linked mirror descent to preconditioned gradient methods via a reference function
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The central convergence guarantees in this paper adapt Lu–Freund–Nesterov’s relative smoothness/convexity to Wasserstein geometry by defining these notions along carefully chosen transport curves.

prior_works.title: The Variational Formulation of the Fokker–Planck Equation
prior_works.authors: Richard Jordan, David Kinderlehrer, Felix Otto
prior_works.role: Established minimizing movement (JKO) schemes and gradient flows in Wasserstein space
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The discrete-time Wasserstein-gradient-based schemes analyzed here build on the JKO paradigm, providing the variational backbone for interpreting gradient-type updates in the space of measures.

prior_works.title: Gradient Flows in Metric Spaces and in the Space of Probability Measures
prior_works.authors: Luigi Ambrosio, Nicola Gigli, Giuseppe Savaré
prior_works.role: Developed the general theory of Wasserstein gradient flows, geodesic convexity, and evolution variational inequalities
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This work supplies the geometric and analytical toolkit—displacement geodesics, convexity notions, and stability—that the paper leverages to define and analyze smoothness/convexity along transport curves.

prior_works.title: A Convexity Principle for Interacting Gases
prior_works.role: Introduced displacement convexity of integral functionals along Wasserstein geodesics
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s key choice of curves and pairings of objectives/regularizers relies on displacement convexity properties in McCann’s sense to obtain convergence of mirror and preconditioned schemes.

prior_works.title: A New Class of Transport Distances Between Measures
prior_works.authors: Jean Dolbeault, Bruno Nazaret, Giuseppe Savaré
prior_works.role: Proposed generalized (mobility-weighted) transport metrics connecting geometry changes to modified gradient flows
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The preconditioned gradient descent in Wasserstein space is conceptually aligned with changing the mobility/metric, and this work provides the geometric interpretation that underpins such preconditioning.

prior_works.title: A Computational Fluid Mechanics Solution to the Monge–Kantorovich Mass Transfer Problem
prior_works.role: Gave the dynamic Benamou–Brenier formulation of W2 and its geodesics
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By characterizing Wasserstein geodesics as solutions of a dynamic optimal transport problem, this work informs the selection of transport paths along which relative smoothness and convexity are assessed.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper’s core contribution—lifting mirror descent and preconditioned gradient descent to Wasserstein space with convergence under relative smoothness/convexity—rests on two intertwined pillars: non-Euclidean first-order optimization and the geometry of optimal transport. Nemirovsky and Yudin introduced mirror descent as a Bregman-regularized method, while Lu–Freund–Nesterov formalized relative smoothness/strong convexity and clarified the equivalence between mirror descent and preconditioned gradient updates via a reference function. The present work transports these ideas from Rd to the space of probability measures by defining the appropriate Bregman regularizers on measures and adapting the relative conditions to hold along carefully chosen curves.
On the geometric side, the JKO scheme and the AGS theory provide the variational and metric foundations for discrete-time and continuous-time Wasserstein gradient flows, including the notions of geodesic (displacement) convexity that drive convergence. McCann’s displacement convexity identifies which functionals behave convexly along Wasserstein geodesics, guiding the authors’ selection of curve families and compatible objective–regularizer pairings. For preconditioning, generalized transport metrics with mobility weights (Dolbeault–Nazaret–Savaré) supply a conceptual bridge: altering the geometry corresponds to a preconditioned flow, which the paper discretizes to obtain provably convergent algorithms. Finally, the Benamou–Brenier dynamic formulation grounds the characterization of transport paths along which the relative smoothness/convexity conditions are verified. Together, these works directly shape the paper’s algorithmic designs and proofs.
